executive_summary: Revenue for debt relief service companies has displayed volatility during the current period. Demand for the industry's services often surges during bad economic times because businesses and individuals have trouble paying their debts. This didn't happen during COVID-19 despite the massive recession because of record-low interest rates and soaring per capita disposable income. These factors enabled consumers to pay their bills and avoid going into more debt, hindering demand for the industry's services and causing revenue to plunge in 2020.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Revenue Plunged During COVID-19 Despite Poor Economic Conditions
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Demand for debt relief services often rises during recessions because individuals and businesses display a drop in income, causing them to take on more debt or struggle to pay their existing obligations. Despite poor economic conditions during the pandemic, revenue fell precipitously in 2020. The Federal Reserve used quantitative easing during COVID-19 to prevent a total economic collapse. This caused interest rates to plunge, making it easier for households and businesses to pay off existing debt and hindering providers' performance.

Profit for debt relief companies is higher than in other industries and sectors because financial firms can keep their prices relatively high. The industry has become less profitable since COVID-19 because of rising per capita disposable income and corporate profit.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: STEADY ECONOMIC GROWTH WILL HINDER DEMAND FOR THE INDUSTRY'S SERVICES
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Despite challenges related to high inflation, rising interest rates and recessionary fears, US GDP will rise steadily during the outlook period. Stable economic growth will boost wages and increase per capita disposable income. This will cause aggregate household debt to fall since consumers will have the increased funds to reduce their liabilities. High GDP growth will cause corporate profit to rise, making it easier for businesses to pay off their debt. As debt burdens for businesses and households fall, demand for the industry's services will diminish, contributing to declining revenue during the outlook period.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: ELEVATED MORTGAGE RATES WILL GIVE DEBT RELIEF COMPANIES A MAJOR REVENUE STREAM
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: While inflation is expected to fall during the outlook period, the Federal Reserve won't reduce interest rates drastically. The central bank wants room to bring them down when a recession occurs. Since interest rates will remain high, debt relief service providers will extract a significant amount of interest income from their existing customers, giving them an essential revenue stream in an environment of falling demand for their services. High-interest rates on mortgages and other products will put some households and businesses in financial trouble, raising downstream demand for the industry's services somewhat.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: FOR-PROFIT DEBT RELIEF SERVICES WILL BE INCREASINGLY VIEWED AS PREDATORY
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: While debt relief service providers claim they want to help struggling consumers get out of financial trouble, critics charge that they offer their customers high-interest loans and other devious financial products to exploit them. Since the industry's companies operate on a for-profit basis, these claims will become more acute. As debt relief companies become viewed as more exploitative, financially struggling consumers will increasingly migrate to non-profit organizations that offer similar services, inducing a long-term decline in demand and revenue for the industry.

industry_definition: Debt relief service providers buy, pool and repackage debt for resale to others on the secondary market. Products include providing loans to households and businesses, trading debt instruments, securities origination and other services.

threats: Regulation for the Investment Management industries

key_trends: Revenue plunged during the current period because of low-interest rates during COVID-19 and rising corporate profit amid the pandemic recovery. The industry has performed better since the cost of borrowing has increased recently.
Demand for debt relief services will enter a long-term decline during the outlook period. Competition with substitutes and solid economic growth will negatively affect the industry.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Debt relief service providers offer loan services to retailers, manufacturers, wholesalers, banks and other businesses to help them manage their liabilities. Players also trade debt instruments and sell securities to banks and other financial institutions.

As the US population has aged and medicine has advanced, hospitals and health care services' share of US GDP has expanded. Since hospitals, clinics and other healthcare centers have grown, they've taken on debt and gone into significant financial trouble. The healthcare sector has become a major market for debt relief service companies as a result.

Since households and individuals often overspend and go into debt, they demand secured and unsecured loans from debt relief service companies. Demand from households often surges during economic crises as unemployed individuals take on more debt to pay their bills.
States and localities often borrow money to fund roads, bridges, schools and other structures.

Not-for-profit organizations sometimes borrow money to build new centers, pay their workers and engage in new advertising campaigns. They demand the industry's services when they get into financial trouble.

products_and_services.product_description: Debt relief service providers help customers combine their liabilities into a single loan with a lower interest rate or better terms so they can reduce their overall interest costs. The industry also negotiates with lenders to help businesses and households secure loans with less debt.
Debt relief service providers offer loan services to retailers, manufacturers, wholesalers, banks and other businesses to help them manage their liabilities.
Debt relief companies have ownership of instruments such as bonds, notes and mortgages, so they sell these debts to other institutions to gain new revenue streams and increase their profit.

Debt relief service providers sometimes securitize their customers' debts into financial instruments, proceeding to sell them to investors. The industry also creates new securities by selling bonds on the market to access funds.
Companies collect fees by offering their customers loans, trading debt instruments and making new securities.

Debt relief service companies may purchase a customer's debt from their original lenders and proceed to offer them an unsecured loan. These loans don't require collateral, so providers take on significant loans when selling these products. To hedge against this risk, debt relief companies offer unsecured loans at much higher interest rates.

tier_1_suppliers: Investment Banking & Securities Intermediation in the US
tier_1_buyers: Finance and Insurance in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Substitutes for debt relief services include credit counseling, financial coaching and filing for bankruptcy. These services have grown in popularity as consumers have started to seek more financial help from non-profit organizations instead of predatory debt service companies.

basis_points.basis_description: Barriers to entry are fairly modest since debt relief service companies don't need to purchase expensive plants or equipment. Start-up costs include financial capital, office space, software, computers and hiring workers. Regulations make it difficult for some individuals to enter the industry.

Market share concentration is fairly low because of localization. Small companies have notoriety in their specific region, encouraging brand loyalty and making it more difficult for large players to compete with them. Modest barriers to entry also hinder consolidation.
Low market share concentration gives companies and households the ability to discriminate based on price, quality of service and reputation.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: The Pandemic Caused Profit to Plunge
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: COVID-19 caused access to credit and per capita disposable income to rise, making it easier for households to pay off debt and constraining revenue and profit.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Rising corporate profit has constrained demand for the industry's services since the pandemic recovery, so debt relief companies' profit hasn't reached pre-pandemic levels.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The industry is fairly labor-intense as workers are necessary for selling debt relief services to customers, analyzing financial data and organizing balance sheets. Since many of these workers will switch jobs if their pay gets cut, players rarely reduce wages even when revenue declines.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The rate of new patent technologies entering the industry is low, which limits the potential for innovations. A low rate does not mean that innovations cannot occur, just that the likelihood of some innovation materializing as a threat is lower.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated, which implies that the market has a focus on key customer segments.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Shifts in Corporate Profit Enhances Volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: When corporate profit is high, companies have more funds to pay off debt and handle existing obligations. As corporate profit falls, businesses borrow more money to pay their bills.
